Kompera

I'd pick either Paralyzing Shells or Take Cover.

The shells are one of the "never runs out" type, they don't (none do) get used with launchers, and you've got 3 weapons and Smart as sabotage protection.

Take Cover is a decent defensive skill and you have the hydroshock already. Plus a few defensive skills for troopers with high kill-shot odds is always a good thing, if barring the offensive skills that let them just rip through the enemy.

karry, it's a tough decision, though. Faceboot won't change a lot his performance, if you want a killer. Think that Laser Sights is a good combination with Hydros. No miss, more chances to a killshot.

On february 9, 2013
Xtremekiwi

On Point is one of the best skills to have. It basically:
Allows you to act before ALL enemy troopers that do not have On Point, except level 15+ enemy spies and in some cases troopers with motorcycles.
Because he's got a CK-M, On Point basically allows the trooper to get 1-2 shots in before the enemies even start moving (Again, except for those who HAVE On Point)
It's absolutely vital for anti-spy.

Cold Blooded, while nice, is vastly inferior to On Point in almost every way.
On february 9, 2013
pickupsticks

There are times that I'd prefer cold blooded. It's an "always on" skill, whereas on point is a one-shot deal at the start of the wave.
If I've got someone with Frenetic (and they're likely to survive the start of the wave without on point to help them) then getting them to shoot faster makes them more likely to survive general combat, as they get the first shot off in an even encounter, and also more likely to keep getting kills and prolong frenzy if they trigger frenetic.

Stolen Ammo was built up around Cold Blooded, although this army is still in the early stages of its development so maybe isn't the best example at this point.

There are a lot of places where I would go with On Point, but it's not as clear-cut to me that this is a snap choice no matter what

On february 11, 2013
ebisan

If you have at least three on point troopers, I'd say you can choose cold blooded with no remorse.
He's clearly a sniper and doesn't look like an anti-spy. On point is vital to act before spies or killing enemy troopers before they have a chance to move. On the other side cold blooded will allow you to shoot faster all the time.
If he is a trooper for your first wave, choose on point no matter what, it will pay off. If he's destined to a second or posterior wave, cold blooded is ok, and you can leave on point and the role of anti-spy to another trooper, I'd say.

For me, the decision weighs more on where you want to place him in your deployment order, and if you want him to be an anti-spy or anti-something. How many troopers with on point in your army also counts.

Spy totally.

It's kind of like swapping 1 trooper for 3.

I suspect that they way OOB works with the spy is like this:

Assuming enemy deployment size is 4, you'd get

Sxxxx xxx

xSxxx xxx

xxSxx xxx

xxxSx xxx

xxxx Sxxx

...as the possible enemy deployments, depending on where your spy was in the order. At least, that's how it works for my OOB troopers on my own side.
If I had a very lethal spy then I'd take the OOB to increase his kill-potential before the next wave arrive with their initiative bonus. If I had a not-so-lethal spy then I wouldn't take OOB, so as to maintain the numberical advantage as much as possible.

On march 10, 2013
Kompera

I'd have taken Tail Gunner. Consider, UMP bursts 3/9, and has 18 capacity. We'll forget about capacity from here on, focusing only on initial performance.

Stock and fully loaded, you get 3 bursts out of it, needing to re-aim twice. With Tail Gunner you get a 5 round and a 4 round burst, and re-aim only once. Damage is 3-4, so assuming all round hit you'll do from 9-12 stock, and 15-20 and 12-16 with Tail Gunner. So stock you're not killing an enemy with a single +3 health boost, and might not even if he's at 10 health. With Tail Gunner in the first burst you're killing even a Commando with +5 health or a low level Soldier, and almost that in the second. Take away the assumption that all round hit and stock damage performance goes down much faster than with Tail Gunner.

Unless you consider your Spy to be a precision killer, and IMO his skills don't lend themselves to that capability, then the UMP functionality with Tail Gunner is superior.

On march 18, 2013
Kompera

BlackBearBut I preffer splash dmg .Shotguns and Launchers have an Area of Effect special. Assault Rifles and Machine Guns have a Spread special.

Shotguns and Launchers are guaranteed the effect, Spread relies on chance.

Here's the wiki text on Spread, poor grammar and all:
Typically, if there are several entities in an area of effect, rounds fired from [assault Rifles and Machine Guns] randomly hit either of entities*, regardless of line of sight. An opponent being Locked does not influence this target randomization. As a result, friendlies risk taking a good portion of Damage and all the nasties a shooter is fitted with.Since Spies deploy on the enemy side, unless two Spies deploy at the same time there's no risk of friendly fire. All Spread rounds will go into enemy Troopers.

With a Machine Gun and their large burst, this typically has the effect of killing the target and wounding one or more Troopers standing nearby. This almost guarantees a Frenetic trigger with the first firing of the Machine Gun, and a Shotgun without Explosive Shells is much less likely to get a kill with a single shot.

That's not to say that a Spy with one of the better Shotguns is poorly equipped. Not at all, they are killing machines. It's just my preference to have a fast Machine Gun over a Shotgun.




* This reads very awkwardly. If they are trying to say that all rounds fired are randomly assigned to all troopers within whatever the Spread AOE is, I disagree. My observation is that most rounds will go to the target, with only a few rounds Spreading to neighboring Troopers.

On march 19, 2013
pickupsticks

Scattergun-guy is kinda like knife-guy in the way I try to use him.
Get close quick because all the time you're out of shooting range you are vulnerable to long range weapons and can't retaliate, hit hard and fast (scattergun and loader is good, but reloading the scattergun is fairly quick anyway) and try to get the enemy before they spread out so that you do maximum damage per shot into the crowd.
Charge serves two purposes. It can get your guy in close quickly and safely, and it can get you out of trouble if you're being attacked when you're in close. Getting a free knockdown on someone buys you a bit of time to reload and then blast them again

Ideally for a scattergunner I'd want frenetic, explosive shells, and sprinter. Restless would work well with frenetic to carry the initiative over into the next wave, but as you've not got frenetic yet and he's not a smart guy so it could be a while before he gets it, I think that charge would work best for this guy here.

I also am not the master at this though... I just like to talk a lot

Kompera

Depending on the rest of your army, I'd probably take Suspicious. It's not a matter of initiative, it's the immunity to damage from fratricide that is potentially important.

If the rest of the crew uses a lot of launchers/grenades/machine guns, then Suspicious becomes a better way to extend the life of the Spy than either of the other skills. If they tend more towards rifles/pistols/assault rifles, then Frenetic would be my choice.

Explosive Shells Chadow.
It's 4x damage when fighting vehicles, if you can get a shotgun it's even more then that.

I don't know the math for sure but it's something like this...
(Shotgun Damage x4) + (Shotgun Damage x2) = total damage to vehicle per hit.

I have seen many spys drop a light tank 1v1 with the combo Explosive Shells + shotgun.

On march 30, 2013
45424
Pause

Explosive Shells Chadow.
It's 4x damage when fighting vehicles, if you can get a shotgun it's even more then that.

I don't know the math for sure but it's something like this...
(Shotgun Damage x4) + (Shotgun Damage x2) = total damage to vehicle per hit.

I have seen many spys drop a light tank 1v1 with the combo Explosive Shells + shotgun.

Shotgun spread damage is different from the main hit. I think it's only 50% of the original blast.
When it hits a tank, it deals damage equal to the main damage + spread damage. Explosive shells chance is calculated on each spread. (You may use up all 6 shells in one blast)

On march 31, 2013
Pause

Hi Alanzhao,
one of the skills in that list must be wrong, it sounds like you are talking about a level 6 trooper.

Talky Walky can bring in an enemy spy. It can be a fun skill and sometimes powerful too but it will also backfire from time to time. It's a risk.

Battle Ready is not a risk. However right now it's also of no use to you.
It can be a powerful skill with the right combo. If you get Battle Ready and then later in the futcher also get some other skills ...say... 'Pilot + Minigun' or 'spy + Semi-Auto Shotgun' only then would Battle Ready become powerful.
Don't bother with Infernal Tube, that Weapon is for troopers who already have Cold Blooded and/or On point.

Your options...
Talky Walky = fun with risk
Battle Ready = useless with great potential

Born-2-kill
Class:scout
Skills:commando heavyweight wrestler face boot
weapons: sniper DBS lizaro jungle
Equipment:hydroshock shells

should i pick
Ck-magellan or binoculars
I advised Ck-mag, but binocular will also be a good perk. I just find Lizaro jungle will not suffice in keeping your trooper in long range and he will often change to sniper or DBS. Worst is with DBS because with speed penalty from heavyweight and heavy weapons, closing in would be lethal to him. If you would pick binocular then likely scenario would be: after burning lizaro and sniper ammo (which will be quite early), he will switch to dbs, he will close-in for shooting range, there's a good chance that you will not outnumber the opponent at this point, with slow speed he will get himself killed and thus will fail using the bino. Of course you can hope to get better weapons later but Ck-M will greatly increase his efficiency of being a long-range killer.

Kompera

He only has Tuck'n'Roll as an avoidance skill to activate Adrenaline. I usually like to see at least two avoidance skills for Adrenaline Troopers. Dodger, Take Cover, Zig Zag, whatever.

I'd rank it:

suspicious > adrenaline > tail gunner

If it was my trooper I'd choose Desert Eagle.

What Hard Boiled does is getting hit on an injured body part will not cause it to take double damage. So rats will deliver successive hits, just that they'll not be able to hit for double damage. As a bonus, headshots no longer do double damage.
On april 20, 2013
Sirron

And you won't have speed/aim penalties from shots to arms and legs.

For a heavily protected guy like him or a soldier with lots of HP, it's awesome.
On april 20, 2013
Xtremekiwi

Invincible is almost required to take advantage of it, though.

On april 28, 2013
Pause

I think you will need the laser sights.

One of the real threats to machine guns and assault weapons is adrenaline.
The heavy machine gun has the lowest aim in the game (equal with the Gatling Gun).

The heavy machine gun has the highest damage in the game (single target and assuming every bullet hits).
The damage will stack with Explosive shells but I think it would be counter intuitive with hydroshock shells.

Also it's range is not great and being slow moving it's a troublesome weapon.
Barrel Extension would lower your need to move and help even more with the aim.
If I was you I would go for these three...

- Laser sights:
- Barrel Extension;
- Explosive shells;

Damage extreme, aim ok, range ok, movmint not so needed.

On may 3, 2013
[344756]

Frankly, I would go with the DBS for your spy. It isn't a bad weapon when your trooper have more then 200 initiative. Here's my take for the choices.


The Gatling isn't a bad choice as a spy weapon, considering that your spy has 30% Speed Bonus, Cold Blooded, On Point, and about 140-150 additional initiative bonus from being a spy(If it works that way). However, you don't have reloading skills or a reliable spare weapon (Like my spy with the Gatling and the PAS.) It is likely that he will resort to punching his enemies once he runs out of ammo.


With the DBS, your spy can spread damage more easily with two shells, and is more likely to reload it. He can also knock down his enemies with the shotgun without using your other troopers or an stolen weapon, allowing him to put the skill "Stamp" to good use. However, you'll be wasting two skills because of it (Trigger Happy and Laser Sights.)


For Desert Eagle, while accurate, it has low ammo and pretty low damage(4). Your spy won't be killing many troopers with it. I would only consider it for a spy if the other choices are unsuitable for a spy.


Sorry for writing so much! I don't like it when people don't explain why they would choose a skill over another one.

On june 16, 2013
[344756]

Damn, this is a real tough one. Moowen can benefit from both skills IMO.

Since Hydroshock is useless with Launchers, you can swap it for BHG. BHG's effect is always useful, even if it's not used often or it doesn't activate Frenetic. It also gives him another way to take down troopers if he is completely sabotaged.

Take Cover will increase the survivability of your trooper as well as helping your trooper reload his weapon more quickly, since he has Adrenaline. This might be useful when Moowen's main weapon is sabotaged and charges to the front lines with his shotgun. It's a safer pick then the BHG, since it will be used more often then the BHG and doesn't take up an equipment slot. Take Cover will be useless if completly sabotaged (Unless Moowen picks up a weapon), and BHG has the potential to take down more troopers then Take Cover and Adrenaline combined.

Basically, what conclusion I'm leading to is this:
For a more offensive trooper, go with BHG
For a trooper with increased survivability, go with Take Cover.

Man, your WSIC posts are always tough ones Doomys. If I had to choose, I would pick Take Cover because of the equipment slots.

  • With frenetic and adrenaline, he has more initiative
  • Juggler, I heard that it affects grenade too

  • Major downfall is that it doesn't proc frenetic and will take a slot which means a wasted level

On june 23, 2013
pickupsticks

Cold Blooded won't increase his initiative, but it will let him make better use of his actions when he does get a turn.
It will also help you to keep frenetic going for longer by reducing the aim time.

Occupation doesn't make any difference to the initiative transfer between waves AFAIK, but it does interfere with incoming enemy troopers by taking up a deployment spot - and usually leaves you in a good spot to take your next shot without having to move (which is more valuable for my knife troopers than for someone with a PAS, but it might have some value) and you're more likely to mess up ALL the incoming troopers with minimum-range-limited weapons.
Less enemy troopers = less chance of some On Point person arriving, so more chance to kill the people that do arrive.

On june 29, 2013
Kompera

Unless there is some special exception for Tuck'n'Roll interaction, it should be either be that you're able to Tuck'n'Roll with Sturdy, or not able to without Sturdy.

The movement penalty for having heavy weapons is applied whether the weapon is held or not. Which makes sense, right? That Bazooka doesn't get any lighter just because you're firing your Desert Eagle.

Check out a Raid round where there are a lot of enemy troopers on the field. Halt play and look them all over, looking for heavy weapons. After you lose, you'll see the clear difference in their speed while running off the field. The more heavy weapons they have they slower they run, even while holding a non-heavy weapon.

On march 25, 2014
Xtremekiwi

Out of all those, I'd take Faceboot, but Out of Bounds would work if you could work your army around that.
What Out of Bounds does is causes the unit to not take up a deployment spot when he's not in a vehicle (Motorcycles excluded)
http://dawnblade.minitroopers.com/b/f...
This battle demonstrates Out of Bounds. Normally, Super Jazoff would not have been able to deploy because I don't have any scouts. However, because Ederg Hunter has Out of Bounds, he didn't take up a deployment slot, letting him enter without counting towards the 4-unit-per-wave limit and thus allowing Super Jazoff to enter.
Helicopter's really only good if the unit has:
1) Bounce Back
2) Fall Guy (Only pilots can get this, getting knocked out of the helicopter causes a LOT of damage)
Alternatively, you can give him a lot of health and hope he doesn't die from the volley that destroyed the heli.
